newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan wants to discuss isle dispute with Japan.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan wants to discuss isle dispute with Japan.

text.p: Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui said on Friday Taipei would seek to negotiate with Tokyo to resolve a sovereignty dispute over a Japan-held East China Sea archipelago.
State television said Lee was deeply concerned by a continuing row over the islands, known in Chinese as the Diaoyus and in Japanese as the Senkakus.
Lee told a group of fishermen that the uninhabited islands, held by Japan but claimed by both Taiwan and China, had been a traditional fishing ground for Taiwan.
The government would seek to negotiate with Japan to protect fishermen's rights, he said.

The president's comments came three days after the latest, but failed, bid by Chinese nationalists from Taiwan to reach the archipelago. They were thwarted after a skirmish with Japanese patrols intent on defending Tokyo's claim of sovereignty.

The island chain has ignited fiery nationalist passions in Chinese communities in Hong Kong and Taiwan since a Japanese right-wing group built a makeshift lighthouse there in July 1996, a move they said bolstered Japan's sovereignty.
China says the uninhabited islets have been Chinese territory for centuries while Japan's claim dates to 1894.
The islands' waters are rich in fish, but experts have said there is no evidence that they hold significant oil deposits.
